title: Judgment and Restoration
shortSummary: Jeremiah 15 records God's declaration of inevitable judgment upon Judah for their persistent sin, despite the intercession of great leaders like Moses and Samuel. The chapter also reveals Jeremiah’s personal anguish and God’s promise of eventual restoration for the faithful remnant.
timeline: c. 626–586 BC - Late Kingdom of Judah, during Jeremiah's prophetic ministry prior to the Babylonian exile

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives God's messages of judgment and restoration and expresses his personal suffering and faithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The great Old Testament leader and intercessor mentioned by God as unable to turn away His judgment on the people.

keyCharacters.name: Samuel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet and judge who, like Moses, is referenced as unable to persuade God to relent from punishing Judah.

keyCharacters.name: Manasseh
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah whose evil deeds in Jerusalem are cited as a cause for God's judgment and exile of the people.

definitions.definition: The practice of charging interest on loans, often considered exploitative; Jeremiah claims he neither lent nor borrowed with usury.
A faithful group of people preserved by God despite widespread judgment and destruction.
A severe scarcity of food that is one of the judgments God pronounces against the people.
The state of being taken prisoner or exiled, specifically referring to Judah’s exile to foreign lands.

outline.heading: God’s Unyielding Judgment Announced
outline.description: God declares that even the intercession of great leaders like Moses and Samuel cannot change His decision to judge Judah, emphasizing the certainty of their punishment and exile.

outline.heading: The Cause and Consequences of Judgment
outline.description: God explains Judah’s rejection and rebellion as the reason for His wrath, describing the devastating effects of war, famine, and loss on the people and their families.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Personal Lament and God’s Assurance
outline.description: Jeremiah expresses his sorrow over being a man of strife and the pain of persecution, yet he also affirms his devotion to God’s word and pleads for God’s remembrance and vindication.

outline.heading: Promise of Restoration and Protection
outline.description: God promises restoration to Jeremiah if he returns to Him, assuring him of divine protection against enemies and deliverance from the wicked.

application: Trust in God’s sovereign judgment even when circumstances seem harsh, knowing He is just and righteous.
Remain faithful and obedient to God’s word, as Jeremiah did, finding joy and strength in Scripture despite opposition.
Seek God’s protection and deliverance through prayer and repentance, confident that He will preserve His faithful remnant.
Understand that suffering for righteousness’ sake is part of the Christian walk, and God will ultimately vindicate His servants.

keyVerses.text: Then said the LORD unto me, Though Moses and Samuel stood before me, yet my mind could not be toward this people: cast them out of my sight, and let them go forth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the certainty of God’s judgment and the futility of human intercession when God’s righteous decision is made.

keyVerses.text: Thy words were found, and I did eat them; and thy word was unto me the joy and rejoicing of mine heart: for I am called by thy name, O LORD God of hosts.
keyVerses.significance: Jeremiah’s declaration shows the sustaining power and joy found in God’s word, even amid suffering.

keyVerses.text: And I will make thee unto this people a fenced brasen wall: and they shall fight against thee, but they shall not prevail against thee: for I am with thee to save thee and to deliver thee, saith the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: God’s promise of protection to Jeremiah assures believers that God is their ultimate defender in spiritual battles.
